learning_outcomes.description: critically read the literature and identify the key ideas

assessments.task_description:
This is an IN-CLASS paper-based exam held during the Week 6 workshop.

The workshop commences at 8:00 am with a one-hour collaborative group activity, after which the exam begins at 9:00 am.

Duration: 100 minutes (10 minutes for planning + 90 minutes working time for assessment).

It will cover the course content studied in Weeks 1-6. It will consist of:

  • multiple choice questions;
  • open-ended questions regarding course content and readings;
  • data analysis emphasising your familiarity with the concepts and their application (it will need to be supported with the research from the relevant required readings).

This assessment will completed on paper in class.

You will have 90 minutes to answer all the question. There will be no time to look for the answers.

You are allowed to use the course material (slides, readings and your notes), but that does NOT mean that you are allowed to copy-paste your answers from the slides or any sources. If you do, you will receive 0 marks for those questions, as that will not show your understanding of the course content, and it might be considered plagiarism leading to the consequences outlined in the UQ academic integrity policy.

STATEMENT ON AI & MT

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

assessments.task_description:
Group project presentation consists of Group Members Evaluation (Mid-point check and End-point check) and the Group project presentation itself.

----

Group Members Evaluation (5%)

Following groups of 4-5 students are formed by the tutor, group members are expected to work collaboratively in designing their group presentation. There will be two Group Members Evaluations conducted through Buddycheck on Blackboard.

  • Mid-point check: Week 8
  • Opens: April 20
  • Closes: April 24 at 5:00 PM
  • End-point check: Week 11
  • Opens: May 10
  • Closes: May 15 at 5:00 PM

Each member of the group will evaluate peer collaboration on a 5-point scale. Students may add a short note to justify their evaluation.

Teaching staff will use the score from both checks and assign a grade based on the rubric for this assessment item.

Important: Based on the mid-point check, your inclusion in the presentation delivery will be determined. If you do not contribute to the project by the end of Week 8, you may not be able to pass this assessment.

-----

Group project presentation (30%)

Develop a presentation in the form of a workshop presentation to raise the audience's Intercultural Communication Awareness/skills in relation to the chosen cultural context, e.g. regional culture, religious groups, educational settings, etc.

This should be approached as an interactive training workshop that would engage the audience.

All students are required to contribute equally to the preparation and delivery.

The group is evaluated as a whole and will receive one score. Considering this, all members must make sure they are contributing effectively to the project and report any issues in their mid-point or end-point Group Members Evaluation to the teaching staff.

Research

Choose a topic that will reflect the theme 'Diversity within cultures', i.e. focus on the microcultural level, NOT national cultures. Find relevant literature to define your topic and your approach to the workshop. In preparation, you are encouraged to have contact with the members of your chosen cultural context, e.g. by interviewing them to gain first-hand knowledge.

Apply at least 2 concepts from the course that are crucial to understand the chosen microculture and provide examples of why those concepts are relevant.

Group presentation guidelines 

Duration: 10 minutes

Key components of your presentation:

  1. Introduce the microcultural context that you have chosen, explaining why you think it is important to raise people's awareness of it.
  2. Introduce your chosen concepts that are crucial to that microculture and its role in terms of intercultural communication. Use readings from the course and additional readings to explain the concepts.
  3. Explain the relevance of the concept with specific examples from that microculture. Examples could be a role-play, short interview, a film segment, or an exercise you developed: be creative. Provide an analysis of examples that aligns with the data analysis done in the course.
  4. Conclude by showing why your chosen cultural context and concept are essential to develop awareness and skills to deal with ICC.

 Key dates

  • Week 4: Group work survey;
  • Week 5: Groups of 4-5 students formed;
  • Week 8: Group Members Evaluation - mid-point
  • Weeks 11: Group Members Evaluation - end-point
  • Weeks 12: Group Presentations

 ! In order to have the best possible experience working with other people, you are advised to complete the 'Working in team' online workshop: https://www.edx.org/course/working-in-teams-a-practical-guide

STATEMENT ON AI & MT

Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

assessments.task_description:
After completing the course and delivering your group presentation, the whole group (n= 4-5 students) is required to attend an oral interview.

During this interview, each group will meet with the tutor to answer a series of questions related to working with your group members during COMU1002. You are required to provide detailed answers—not brief responses such as “yes,” “no,” “good,” or “I didn’t notice anything.”

Your answers should demonstrate:

  • Your understanding of any challenges your group may have faced.
  • Your critical reflection on how you and your group approached these challenges in relation to the course content.

Each group will be allocated approximately 20-25 minutes for the interview.

The questions will include:

  • A review of your responses to the Group Members Evaluation (mid-point and end-point).
  • Discussion of your presentation in Week 12.
  • Your reflection on the main topics of COMU1002, i.e., key theories and concepts in intercultural communication.

You should be prepared to respond to questions about:

  • Your contribution and performance within the group.
  • Your understanding of the concepts used in your own presentation.

Each member is marked individually. For more detail, please refer to the marking criteria on Blackboard. 

The Week 13 tutorial will include practice interviews to prepare students for the final interviews.
